text: - Hello, and welcome to Community Chats.
I'm Aley Hammer.
And today we're joined with Neil Maclure

the head of cloud and technology
services over at CoverMore.
Neil, welcome to the show.

CoverMore is a global brand
with multiple subsidiaries
but for those who might not know,
can you start by telling our audience
a little bit about CoverMore?
- Thank you so much, Aley,

and it's a pleasure to
be talking to you today.

It's wonderful to be in
the offices of AWS as well.
To your earlier question,

CoverMore of those that are
not aware is a global brand.
So we're a global insurance company.

We started up in Sydney now
about 36 years ago in 1986.
And through these last 36 years
we've grown to be a global brand.

We specialize predominantly
in travel insurance
but we also have medical assistance
and employee assistance as well.

For those again, that don't
know, we fit into a much broader
and much larger our mothership

as I like to call it
is the Zurich business

which I'm sure our audience
know well and truly about.
- Thank you so much, Neil.
And CoverMore has recently gone through
a very successful migration in APAC.
So why did you choose the cloud
and specifically why did you choose AWS?
- Oh, that's a two part question.

If you don't mind Aley,
I'll try and break it up

and see if I can do
justice to that question.
So the first part is why cloud?
This was actually top of mind.

We did have a compelling
event in the business.

And when I meant a compelling
event, what that was is,

we all of a sudden were faced
with a data center exit.

So we had to get out of our
data centers within six months,
we were given a six month notice period
and we had to get out of it.

So that compelling event,
we looked at where we were
and we looked at

how we can actually
strategically go forward.
There was absolutely no point in moving
from tin to tin as I like to call it,

from a pizza box set up to
another pizza box set up,
it just didn't make sense.

So when we first were faced
with this compelling event
I sat down with our ELT and I positioned

that either ways we
wanted to get to the cloud
but the compelling event accelerated that.
So number one was a compelling event
which is the data sets exit.

The other aspect was
flexibility and scalability.

CoverMore as a group is
growing exponentially,

especially now that we
are out of the pandemic.
What we are seeing in the marketplaces,
we are exponentially...
The interest from our customer base
is exponentially growing.
And we always knew that operating out of,

if you like our data
centers was the limitation.
It presented scalability issues.
It presented flexibility issues

in how we actually service
our customers, et cetera.

So the second one was
flexibility and scalability

but then we also knew
that moving to the cloud
would significantly enhance our BCP,
our business continuous planning
and our disaster recovery process.

Straight away from
moving from data centers

and into the cloud that
gave us that capability
which we never had before.

And that was an area from
an audit perspective.

We were constantly having to
double down and triple down

and a lot of effort was
going into that area.
So moving to the cloud there again
it was a no brainer.
Data, the other aspect was data,
enabling an effective data strategy.

Again, having all of our
workloads, et cetera,

sitting in on-prem, it kind
of locks you in many ways

from a data and a data
execution perspective.

By unlocking it and by
moving to the cloud,
that automatically starts to unlock
what we could do with our data,
how we could actually get data
to present new customers to us.
So we are right now, right in the middle
of trying to work out
how we can leverage that data strategy.

And we wouldn't be here without
the enabling of the cloud
or the enabler being the cloud.
And lastly, but most importantly

we are growing rapidly within
various regions of the globe.

And as part of that,
one of our pain points
or one of the points

that we are trying to
very quickly get better at
is our target operating model.

Now moving into one
central platform globally

in various different
geographies makes that possible.

So for all these five,
six different data points
it just was absolutely obvious

as to why we should be
moving to the cloud.

And to your part two
of your question, Aley

which I'm very passionate about
in the background as well,
is why AWS?
For us AWS

was the most fit for purpose
hyperscaler in market.

AWS simply, the team at AWS,
it was the people at AWS,
it's the products, it's the services,

it's the customer obsession
that you bring to the table.
But all of that was the soft aspects.
The real aspects for us is security wise.

AWS absolutely stood out
and it was a no brainer.
If we wanted to secure our workload,
secure our platforms, et cetera,
with AWS is enhanced security
and virtual organization, et cetera.
It was a no brainer.

So security, scalability,
backups, flexibility

and more importantly,
AWS, you just get us,
as a business you understand who we are,

you understand the levers that
we have within the business.
And you actually understood
that we were going through a pandemic,
in a pandemic situation

a travel insurance brand
takes the biggest hit.
And you were right beside us.
When we set up our operations in EMIR,
you stood right beside us.
And we asked you to pivot and scale
and deliver within months.
You absolutely delivered on that.
So when it came to move,

when it came to addressing
our APAC issues,
it was no brainer.
AWS was the obvious choice.
- Wow, Neil, what a testimonial.
I mean, I always ask that question
to every single customer I interview
but that is definitely
one of the best responses I've ever heard.
Thank you so much.
That's so great to hear that.

And we feel the exact same way
about you guys at CoverMore.
So thank you so much for that.
Neil, I know when you move to the cloud
there are often challenges.

Of course, when you're
transitioning to AWS,

there are big icebergs
that get in the way.
So how did you overcome them?

And also, were there any
parts of the business
that were quite reluctant to move to AWS?

I know you had that six
month kind of time limit.

So for you guys, it might
have been a little bit easier
to persuade the leadership team
but I did wanna know was anyone reluctant

and also what were some
of those big challenges
that you did overcome?

- Again, Aley, I'll try and
do just to your question.
That's actually a very pertinent
and a very top of mind question
for a lot of transformations that happen.
So why do we firstly,

I find when you're looking
at a transformation program,

the bigger the obstacles or
the larger the challenges

I find that makes the
transformation to any customer,
all the more meaningful
and tackling those big boulders upfront
and addressing them and unpacking them

with the various blended
teams and our partners

right beside us, it just
makes it even more satisfying.
When you're sitting in front of your ELT,
you're sitting in front of your board

and basically saying, this
is where we were last year.

And look what we've done
with our partners this year,

that makes a transformation
all the most satisfying.

And then again, it comes down
to that customer obsession,
basically enabling that journey.

But to answer your question
a lot more directly, Aley,
I think that the biggest challenge

in a transformation program
or cloud migration program
is that education piece.

It's that basically
making sure that your ELT,
right from your ELT, right down through

to your the other various
teams, the developer teams,
et cetera, they're all on the same page.
And they understand the vision,
they understand what's at stake

and they understand when
we get to that end state

what it unlocks, the various
opportunities that it unlocks,

not just for our internal
people, but for our customers.
That is the exciting part

and also the biggest challenge
as well, is making sure
that the various teams come together
and are all on the same page
and understand the challenge and value.
- Some great advice.
So, Neil, thank you so much.

I mean, you've successfully
migrated to the cloud already.
So what is next for CoverMore

in terms of modernization
or product innovation?
Can you give us some insight into that?
- Aley that's again, a lovely question.

And if you don't mind, I
feel like like a teenager

who has the keys to a
Ferrari sitting in the garage

and our ELT also feel the
same way I should say.
We've just moved into a brand new platform
and we've got this brand new platform
and we're starting to work out, okay,
where do we go from here?

And top mind for us is
there's four pillars that...

or four key areas we'd
like to start exploring is,
one is our data strategy,

and what does it actually mean
to redefine our data strategy

to figure out what a
modern data architecture
looks like on AWS?
That's the first thing.

We just need to work out,
okay, you've got this dash,
what does that dashboard do?
And how do we leverage it to?
- That's the question, right?

A million dollar question,
you have the data,
what do you do with it?
- What do we do with it?

And how can we get the
data to give us a view

of our customers that we've
never been able to see before?
And what does a modern data architecture
for the enterprise looks like?
All this is very exciting for us.
So that's the first piece.

The second piece is all of
a sudden being on a platform

now gives us the ability to
modernize our core platforms.
As you know, the insurance tech stack

is a very unique type of stack
and it requires a lot of TLC.

So again, now that we
are basically on AWS,
what does that mean?
Can we move to an RTS state?
What is the elastic containerizations
or container services actually do for us?
That again, top of mind, very exciting.
The teams that basically work with these
on a day to day basis are static about it.
It's like new toys.
Optimization and education,
given this is a consumption driven model,
what's top of mind for a lot of us is
we need to start educating the business on
this being a consumption driven model
the behaviors that come with it,

or the behaviors that
basically we need to leverage
to make this work for us.

We need to vigorously execute
and drive optimization,
visibility through the businesses.
One of the end states that we have in mind
that we'd like to execute.
And again, we are a bit far...
We had a couple months

is to be able to give the
business units those levers,

to see exactly, what
consumption actually means.

And so for them to be
able to know exactly,
today we are dropping a product

and tomorrow our cost base is
going to grow by X percentage.
That's a very powerful lever.
And that's something that us being able

to provide the business that
is an even more powerful lever.

It all of a sudden starts
to unlock our visibility,
transparency and it starts to give you

that view on exactly how
effective a product can be

in the marketplace, I suppose,
that's that point of it.

And the last point, I
suppose, at least innovation.

Now that we are on a performing
and a scalable platform

a key ask from the business
is to clearly articulate

how does that play now into
our appetite to innovate?

What does that mean
for product innovation.

Now that we've got the tools
to be able to innovate,
what does that actually mean?
How can we leverage that
to drive innovation through the business?

So these are some things
that are top of mind.

And if you find your way
into CoverMore one day,

and you sort of eavesdrop
on our conversation,

you'll find that these
are some of the things
that we're talking about.
And this is from a place of excitement.
So that's where we are.
I hope I've answered your question, Aley.
- Absolutely.
I mean, you make tech very exciting.
We love partnering with you, Neil.
Thank you so much for coming on the show
and sharing the cloud journey.
And as I mentioned, you're so infectious,
your love for technology

and as you say, it's like
the keys to the Ferrari.

So we're so glad that
you enjoy the tech sack
as much as we do.
And we've just love partnering with you.
So thank you so much, Neil.

If anyone has any
questions about CoverMore
or any of the tech that they're using,

please pop them in the
comment section below,
and we'll get back to you.
Thanks so much, Neil.
- Thank you Aley, much appreciate it.
Thank you for your time.
